conclusion: Understanding the problem involves two objects moving along the same line with velocities plotted against time.
In a v-t graph, the area under the curve gives the displacement of an object.
The distance between the objects is the difference in their displacements.
Object A has a straight line increasing linearly, indicating constant acceleration. Object B has a curve indicating changes in velocity.
To find when they are farthest apart, find the time when the difference in their displacements is maximum.
For object A: v_A = kt, where k is the slope of the line.
For object B: v_B is the curved line with a minimum point.
The difference in displacements is |displacement_A - displacement_B|.
Consider the function difference(t) = displacement_A - displacement_B to find its maximum.
Positions at any time t are Position_A = (1/2)kt^2 and Position_B = displacement_B.
Consider the relative velocity v_B - v_A.
Relative displacement is the integral of (v_B - v_A) dt.
Distance is maximized when the accumulated area of relative displacement is maximized.
At t=0, v_A = 0 and v_B is positive.
v_B - v_A starts positive, decreases, possibly becomes negative, then increases.
Maximum area under the curve of v_B - v_A indicates maximum distance.
Estimate areas under each curve to find maximum difference.
